entry.title: Re: SAC Data Action: DELETE() with IF condition not working
entry.content:
Hi @AmirL 

The issue you are facing is related to the behavior of Dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas. When you define the MEMBERSET using the "All" node or "Parent member ID" of the hierarchy, Advanced Formulas may produce results that differ from what you expect.
 
To obtain the desired results when using a MEMBERSET defined with the "All" node or a "Parent member ID" of the hierarchy, you can modify the script as follows.
  • IF [d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL] !== [d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY].[p/Material] THEN
       DELETE()
    ENDIF
For more details on the behavior of dimension member comparison, please refer to the following SAP Blog.
  • The behavior of dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas

 

I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: Email verification for provisioned users - IAS
entry.content:
@tskwin 

Below is the transformation for sending email .. By default is set to false (email won't be sent) and if you turn to true.. email goes... 

for Email verified flag .. you can set to verified using true but when you send the email, it automatically it turns to verified or non-verified.. so that you know they haven't verified yet nor logged in yet.

      {
        "constant": false,
        "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['sendMail']",
        "scope": "createEntity"
      },
      {
        "constant": true,
        "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['mailVerified']",
        "scope": "createEntity"
      },

entry.title: Developing AI Enabled Applications with ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM
entry.content:
SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities is your intelligent coding companion, bringing deep expertise in ABAP Cloud and AI-driven development. When we talk about ABAP AI use cases, they revolve around three key pillars — Accelerate, Empower, and Transform. Each AI capability is delivered as part of these pillars, helping developers enhance productivity, build smarter applications, and drive innovation. To learn more about SAP Joule for Developers, refer to the blog post Joule speaks ABAP! by Dr. Alexander Rother.

Have you ever wondered how to infuse intelligence into your ABAP-based business applications and move beyond standard transactional scenarios? If yes, you’ve landed at the right place. In this blog, we’ll explore how you can build AI-enabled applications using the ABAP AI SDK powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM), the main deliverable of the Empower use case.

The Scenario 
The goal of this scenario is to infuse generative AI into an ABAP Cloud application to enhance user experience and automate content creation. 

Use Case: Build an ABAP Cloud application to generate a travel itinerary for a given city based on user input, along with a budget breakdown, using ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM. 

Which products are supported? 

The ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM is available in: 

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment  
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA OnPrem as of release 2025 via standard delivery. Lower releases of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA OnPrem are supported via Transport-based Correction Instructions (TCI), see details in SAP Note 3513374 and the SAP Notes and instructions linked therein. 

Overview 

To build this application, we’ll bring together several key components: 

  • SAP AI Core – for managing AI scenarios and accessing generative AI capabilities via the generative AI hub. 
  • Communication Arrangement – to establish secure integration between ABAP and AI Core. 
  • ISLM (Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management) and ABAP AI SDK – for seamless integration with Generative AI Hub, SAP BTP AI services 
  • Custom ABAP Cloud Application – to embed and expose AI capabilities through a user-friendly application. 

 Implementation Steps 

  1. Set Up the Environment 
    Configure the AI Core service plan and establish communication arrangements between the ABAP system and AI Core.
  2. Build Custom Travel Plan ABAP Cloud application. 
  3. Create and Deploy Intelligent Scenarios 
    Define the AI scenario in ISLM, train or connect your model, and deploy it for consumption. 
  4. Consume Intelligent Scenarios in ABAP 
    Integrate the deployed scenario within a custom ABAP Cloud application to generate AI-driven outputs - in this case, travel itineraries and budget breakdown. 

1. Set Up the Environment  

  1. Configure the required entitlements to make SAP AI Core accessible in your subaccount. To use Generative AI capabilities (including the Generative AI Hub and LLM access), choose the extended service plan. To add a Service Plan, see : Add a Service Plan | SAP Help Portal 
     
  2. Download the client default certificate of the ABAP system to create the X.509 service key in AI Core instance. Follow the steps here : Download Certificate | SAP Help Portal 
     
  3. Create a service instance and service key for accessing SAP AI Core, where the large language models in the generative AI hub are hosted. The X.509 service key is created with the downloaded client default certificate of the ABAP system passed as parameter. Follow the steps from here: Create SAP BTP Service Instance and Key | SAP Help Portal

  4. Configure communication system for SAP_COM_0A69. Currently, you can create one instance of the communication scenario per client. Follow the steps from here: How to Configure the Communication System for SAP_COM_0A69 | SAP Help Portal
     
  5. To create the Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0A69. Follow the steps from here: How to Create the Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0A69 | SAP Help Portal 

  6. After the communication system and communication arrangement are configured, create an intelligent scenario and continue managing the lifecycle of the intelligent scenario. You are required to create an intelligent scenario for your custom owned Gen AI use cases. 

2. Create a custom ABAP Cloud Application to infuse AI Capabilities 

2.1 Create Package

  1. In ADT, go to the Project Explorer, right-click on the package ZLOCAL, and select New > ABAP Package from the context menu.
  2. Maintain the required information: 
    1. Name: ZTRAVEL_ITINERARY
    2. Description: ABAP AI Capabilities
      Select the box Add to favorites package. Click Next and Finish.

 2.2 Create database table 

Create a database table to store the Travel Itinerary data.

  1. Right-click on your ABAP package ZTRAVEL_ITINERARY and select New > Other ABAP Repository Object from the context menu.
  2. Search for database table, select it, and click Next.
  3. Maintain the required information: Name: ZRAP_TRAVEL_DATA   Description: Database Table for Travel Itinerary
  4. Click Next. Click Finish and Replace the default code with the code snippet provided below 

 

@EndUserText.label : 'Database table for travel Itinerary'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zrap_travel_data {
  key client            : abap.clnt not null;
  key travel_id         : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  traveler_name         : abap.char(80);
  starting_point        : abap.char(100);
  destination           : abap.char(100);
  start_date            : /dmo/begin_date;
  end_date              : /dmo/end_date;
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zrap_travel_data.budget_curr'
  budget                : abap.curr(15,2);
  budget_curr           : abap.cuky;
  transport_mode        : abap.char(40);
  accommodation_type    : abap.char(50);
  ai_itinerary          : abap.sstring(1333);
  ai_budget_breakdown   : abap.sstring(1000);
  status                : abap.char(20);
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;
}

        5. Save and activate the changes in the table ZRAP_TRAVEL_DATA

2.3 Generate transactional UI service

Create your OData v4 based UI service with the built-in ADT generator. The generated business service will be transactional, draft-enabled, and enriched with UI semantics for the generation of the Fiori elements app.

  1. Right-click your database table ZRAP_TRAVEL_DATA and select Generate ABAP Repository Objects from the context menu.


  2. Select OData UI Service and click Next and provide the package details.

     

  3.  Maintain the required information on the Configure Generator dialog to provide the name of your data model and generate them.
  4. For that, navigate through the wizard tree (Business Objects, Data Model, etc…), maintain the artefact names provided and press Next.
  5. Verify the maintained entries and press Next to confirm. Click on Finish.


  6. The artifacts needed will be generated. Go to the Project Explorer, select your package ZRAP_TRAVEL_ITENERARY, refresh it by pressing F5, and check all generated ABAP repository objects.



    ℹ️NOTE: The names of the artifacts may differ from those shown in this Blog, as they are generated by the wizard.

2.4 Adjust meta data extensions
Open the metadata extension ZC_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA and make the adjustments as shown in the code snippet below ZC_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA should look like this:

 

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
@UI.headerInfo.title.type: #STANDARD
@UI.headerInfo.title.value: 'TravelID'
@UI.headerInfo.description.type: #STANDARD
@UI.headerInfo.description.value: 'TravelID'

annotate view ZC_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA with
{
  @ui.facet: [
    { label: 'General Information', id: 'GeneralInfo', purpose: #STANDARD, position: 10, type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE },
    { label: 'AI Generated Itinerary', id: 'AIItineraryFacet', purpose: #STANDARD, position: 200, type: #FIELDGROUP_REFERENCE, targetQualifier: 'AI_ITIN' },
    { label: 'AI Budget Breakdown', id: 'AIBudgetFacet', purpose: #STANDARD, position: 210, type: #FIELDGROUP_REFERENCE, targetQualifier: 'AI_BUDGET' }
  ]

  @EndUserText.label: 'TravelID'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 10, label: 'TravelID' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 10, label: 'TravelID' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 10 } ]
  TravelID;

  @EndUserText.label: 'TravelerName'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 20, label: 'TravelerName' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 20, label: 'TravelerName' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 20 } ]
  TravelerName;

  @EndUserText.label: 'StartingPoint'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 30, label: 'StartingPoint' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 30, label: 'StartingPoint' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 30 } ]
  StartingPoint;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Destination'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 40, label: 'Destination' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 40, label: 'Destination' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 40 } ]
  Destination;

  @ui.identification: [ { position: 50 } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 50 } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 50 } ]
  StartDate;

  @ui.identification: [ { position: 60 } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 60 } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 60 } ]
  EndDate;

  @EndUserText.label: 'Budget'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 70, label: 'Budget' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 70, label: 'Budget' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 70 } ]
  Budget;

  @EndUserText.label: 'TransportMode'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 80, label: 'TransportMode' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 80, label: 'TransportMode' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 80 } ]
  TransportMode;

  @EndUserText.label: 'AccommodationType'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 90, label: 'AccommodationType' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 90, label: 'AccommodationType' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 90 } ]
  AccommodationType;


  // FULL-WIDTH AI ITINERARY
  @EndUserText.label: 'Generated Itinerary'
  @ui.fieldGroup: [ { qualifier: 'AI_ITIN', position: 10, label: 'AI Generated Itinerary' } ]
  @ui.multiLineText: true
  AiItinerary;


  // FULL-WIDTH AI BUDGET
  @EndUserText.label: 'Budget Breakdown'
  @ui.fieldGroup: [ { qualifier: 'AI_BUDGET', position: 10, label: 'AI Budget Breakdown' } ]
  @ui.multiLineText: true
  AiBudgetBreakdown;


  @EndUserText.label: 'Status'
  @ui.identification: [ { position: 120, label: 'Status' } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ { position: 120, label: 'Status' } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ { position: 120 } ]
  Status;

   @EndUserText.label: '_BaseEntity'
  @ui.identification: [ {
    position: 180 , 
    label: '_BaseEntity'
  } ]
  @ui.lineItem: [ {
    position: 180 , 
    label: '_BaseEntity'
  } ]
  @ui.selectionField: [ {
    position: 180 
  } ]
  _BaseEntity;

  

}

 2.5 Preview travel app

1. Publish the local service endpoint of your service binding and start the Fiori elements App Preview. Open your service binding ZUI_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA_O4 and click Publish.

2. Double-click on the Entity ZC_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA in the Entity Set and Association section to open the Fiori elements App Preview.

For Reference  : Create Database Table and Generate UI Service | SAP Tutorials

3. Create an Intelligent Scenario (Generative AI) 
 

You first need to create an intelligent scenario for your custom Generative AI use cases. This scenario acts as the central place to manage the entire lifecycle of your AI asset from setup to generating inference results. All lifecycle steps can be executed through the Intelligent Scenario Management app.Below are the key steps to create an intelligent scenario: 

3.1 Create ISLM Scenario

An intelligent scenario is an ABAP representation of a predictive business-specific use case. These intelligent scenarios are AI-powered workflows or processes designed to automate and optimize business tasks.  

  1. Select your package, right-click, New → Other → Intelligent Scenario → ZINTS_RAP120


  2. Enter a name and description. Select SIDEBYSIDE for Scenario Technology field. Press Next


  3. Set the following parameters to the created Intelligent Scenario

Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management supports two primary types of intelligent scenarios:

Embedded Scenarios

Embedded scenarios are built and executed within SAP S/4HANA using the ABAP platform. They rely on the in-database machine learning capabilities of SAP HANA, such as: HANA Predictive Analysis Library (PAL),Automated Predictive Library (APL)

Side-by-Side Scenarios

Side-by-side scenarios, where SAP S/4HANA runs in a separate stack than its machine learning infrastructure provider, such as SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). These scenarios use external ML services or custom ML models.
Generative AI,SAP AI Core,Data Attribute Recommendation

  • For our scenario we will be using the side by side scenarios type, sap SAPGEN AI
    Turnkey Enablement: Automatically enable SAP-delivered (turnkey) GenAI use cases with minimal configuration effort.

 

Field

Value

Intelligent Scenario Type

SAPGENAI

Automate Turnkey Switch On

Check the checkbox

Usage Type

CUSTOMER

 

  1. Activate the object.

3.2 Create ISLM Model
1. Select your package, right-click, New → Other → Intelligent Scenario Model

2. Fill the Description and Model Name fields. Assign the previous created scenario in Intelligent Scenario Name. Click on Next 


3. Enter the ExecutableID and Large Language Model Name and Large Language Model Version

 

Field

Possible values

Executable Id

o        aicore-sap

o        aws-bedrock

o        azure-openai

o        gcp-vertexai

Large Language Model Name

It depends on the Executable Id

Large Language Model Version

One option is to leave the version field free, then the latest version will be used. This helps to avoid issues in case that the model has been deprecated in AI Core
 More info. https://me.sap.com/notes/3437766

 

 4. Through the Prompt Library API, we can use predefined prompt templates to generate new prompts. Currently prompt templates are defined through ISLM. In order to get an instance of the prompt template you want to use, you need to provide the ISLM scenario and the ID of the prompt template.Click on Add and provide the following Details. 
Prompt Template Name: SYSTEM_PROMPT_ITIN 
Prompt Template:System prompt for generating Itinerary 
Prompt: You are a professional travel planner. Create a {ISLM_days} day itinerary for a given destination, including daily highlights, must-visit spots and activities. Keep it under 1000 characters. 
 

 

 5. The prompt Parameters is captured from the prompt template after activation. 

 

6. Add another prompt template for User prompt. 
Prompt Template Name: USER_PROMPT_ITIN 
Prompt Template:User prompt template 
Prompt: Destination: {ISLM_destination} Departure: {ISLM_startingpoint} Travel Dates: {ISLM_startdate} to {ISLM_enddate}  Mode of Transport: {ISLM_transportmode} Accommodation Type: {ISLM_accommodationtype} Generate the itinerary now 
  
 

7. Activate the object
WARNING : Before you try the ABAP AI SDK out in an ABAP Class, please make sure that the deployment is running  

3.3 In Fiori Launchpad

To use the Intelligent Scenarios and Intelligent Scenario Management apps, you must have the appropriate access rights to the SAP Fiori Launchpad. The access for ISLM is added to the business role of an analytics specialist; BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST.
 You can create and manage ISLM Scenarios through Intelligent Scenario Management app.

You can check your previously created scenario in the Intelligent Scenario Management Fiori App.
In the next step Instantiate ABAP AI SDK using the created ISLM Scenario 

3.4. Consume Intelligent Scenarios in ABAP

ABAP AI SDK
The ABAP AI SDK powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM) is an ABAP reuse library that supports you in interacting with large language models (LLMs) hosted on the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core. Using the ABAP AI SDK, you can build your own AI-based features in ABAP.

Completion API
This API provides access to the completion API functionality of Large Language Models (LLMs), meaning that it uses an LLM to generate a text response from a prompt.

Prompt Library API
Using the prompt library API, you can use prompt templates predefined via ISLM to generate new prompts.

Catchable Exceptions
The execution of the completion API may cause an error and therefore CX_AIC_COMPLETION_API can be caught as a result. When the error is triggered by the LLM itself or by the AI service provider, CX_AIC_COMPLETION_API provides further information about the error.

Add a determination to the Travel Business Object and enhance it with the ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM. Define the determination generateAIItinerary in the behavior definition ZR_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA and implement it in the behavior implementation class, aka behavior pool ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.

1.Add the mandatory fields. Go to the Project Explorer and open your behaviour definition ZR_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.

field ( readonly )
TravelID,
Status,
AiBudgetBreakdown,
AiItinerary,
LocalCreatedBy,
LocalCreatedAt,
LocalLastChangedBy,
LocalLastChangedAt,
LastChangedAt;

field ( mandatory : create )
TravelerName,
EndDate,
StartDate,
Budget,
AccommodationType,
StartingPoint,
TransportMode,
Destination;

determination generateAIItinerary on modify { create; }

  Define the generateAIItinerary determination:

  1. Save and activate the changes in ZR_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.
  2. Declare the required method in behavior implementation class ZBP_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA using ADT Quick Fix  Ctrl/Cmd + 1.

     

     

  3. Save and activate the changes in ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.
  4. Let's implement the determination generateAIItinerary. In your implementation class ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA, In generateAIItinerary method implementation.
  5. Replace the following code. Your code should look like this:

 METHOD generateAIItinerary.
    LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(ls_key).
      READ ENTITIES OF zr_rap_travel_data IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY ZrRapTravelData
      FIELDS ( destination startdate enddate transportmode accommodationtype     BudgetCurr ) WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
      RESULT DATA(lt_travel).
      LOOP AT lt_travel INTO DATA(ls_travel).
        DATA(days) = ls_travel-enddate - ls_travel-startdate + 1.
        DATA(itinerary) = ``.
        DATA(budget)    = ``.
        IF ls_travel-AiItinerary IS INITIAL OR ls_travel-AiBudgetBreakdown IS INITIAL.
          TRY.

*Calling the Prompt Library API.Through the Prompt Library API, we can use predefined prompt templates to generate new prompts.

              FINAL(sys_prompt_template_instance) =  cl_aic_islm_prompt_tpl_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                   islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' template_id = 'SYSTEM_PROMPT_ITIN' ).
              " Add a system prompt based on an ISLM prompt template with one parameter
              FINAL(sys_prompt) = sys_prompt_template_instance->get_prompt( parameters = VALUE #( ( name  = 'ISLM_days'    value = days  ) ) ).

              " Add a user prompt based on an ISLM prompt template with parameters
              FINAL(user_prompt_template_instance) =  cl_aic_islm_prompt_tpl_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                  islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' template_id = 'USER_PROMPT_ITIN' ).

              FINAL(user_prompt) = user_prompt_template_instance->get_prompt( parameters = VALUE #(
     ( name  = 'ISLM_startdate'
       value =  |{ ls_travel-startdate }| )
     ( name  = 'ISLM_enddate'
       value = |{ ls_travel-enddate }| )
         ( name  = 'ISLM_startingpoint'
       value = ls_travel-StartingPoint )
           ( name  = 'ISLM_destination'
       value = ls_travel-Destination )
     ( name  = 'ISLM_transportmode'
       value = ls_travel-transportMode )
        ( name  = 'ISLM_accommodationtype'
       value = ls_travel-accommodationtype )
   ) ) .




              FINAL(api_itin) = cl_aic_islm_compl_api_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                      islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' ).

*Set the LLM parameters
              FINAL(params) = api_itin->get_parameter_setter( ).
              params->set_maximum_tokens( 800 ).


              FINAL(msg_itin) = api_itin->create_message_container( ).
              msg_itin->set_system_role( sys_prompt ).
              msg_itin->add_user_message( user_prompt ).
              itinerary = api_itin->execute_for_messages( msg_itin )->get_completion( ).
            CATCH cx_aic_api_factory INTO DATA(lx_api_itin).
              itinerary = |AI instance creation failed for itinerary.|.
            CATCH cx_aic_completion_api INTO DATA(lx_comp_itin).
              itinerary = |AI completion call failed for itinerary.|.
          ENDTRY.
          IF itinerary IS NOT INITIAL.
            TRY.

* To pass prompts directly without prompt parameters
* Your ISLM scenario for itinerary

                DATA(system_prompt_budget) =
                  |You are a travel finance advisor. Based on the Itenary , destination, duration, | &&
                  |and total budget, estimate how much to allocate for travel, hotel, | &&
                  |food, sightseeing, and miscellaneous expenses. Output under 500 characters.|.
                DATA(user_prompt_budget) =
                  |Itenerary: { itinerary }| &&
                  |Departure: { ls_travel-StartingPoint }| &&
                 |Destination: { ls_travel-destination }| &&
                  |\nTravel Dates: { ls_travel-startdate } to { ls_travel-enddate }| &&
                  |\nTotal Budget: ₹{ ls_travel-Budget }| &&
                  |\nTotal Budget Currency: ₹{ ls_travel-BudgetCurr }| &&
                  |\nProvide a short, realistic breakdown.|.
                FINAL(api_budget) = cl_aic_islm_compl_api_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                      islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' ).
                " Your ISLM scenario for budget
                FINAL(msg_budget) = api_budget->create_message_container( ).
                msg_budget->set_system_role( system_prompt_budget ).
                msg_budget->add_user_message( user_prompt_budget ).
                budget = api_budget->execute_for_messages( msg_budget )->get_completion( ).
              CATCH cx_aic_api_factory INTO DATA(lx_api_budget).
                budget = |AI instance creation failed for budget.|.
              CATCH cx_aic_completion_api INTO DATA(lx_comp_budget).
                budget = |AI completion call failed for budget.|.
            ENDTRY.
          ENDIF.
          MODIFY ENTITIES OF zr_rap_travel_data  IN LOCAL MODE
            ENTITY ZrRapTravelData
           UPDATE FIELDS ( aiitinerary aibudgetbreakdown status )
            WITH VALUE #(
              ( %tky = ls_travel-%tky
                aiitinerary        = itinerary
                aibudgetbreakdown = budget
                status              = 'Generated' )
            ).
        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.
  1. Save and activate the changes in ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.
  2. Preview and test the enhanced Travel Itinerary App with Generative AI Capabilities.

 

 

 

For latest updates, subscribe to the blog posts below : 

ABAP AI - Chapter 2 - SAP Community

Introducing the Next Era of ABAP Development - SAP Community

Joule speaks ABAP! - SAP Community

From Legacy to AI-Powered: RISE Transformation Rev... - SAP Community

Happy Learning!

entry.title: Re: Migration Manager Protection is disabled and you are...
entry.content:
Hi VictorG_inycom,

There is internal setting which controls if Migration Manager works with protected files or not. This settings is not available to admins from the Setup, that is why you don't see it and you can't find documentation about it. This protection is added from the security reasons some time ago. But unfortunately it seems that it was not turned on for all tenants. 

If it happens that one tenant is having this turned on and the other is not, then that message is displayed. To resolve your situation, you need to raise a Support ticket and tell them which tenants are you working with, and they will turn on protection on all of them, so you can continue to migrate freely between them. 

We will investigate the situation and plan for future to have this settings on for all tenants on all environments to avoid others running into the same problem.

 

Best regards

  Lana Nikolic-Cvijic 

(Product Manager of Advanced Workflow)

entry.title: Period and volume discount not seen in sap customer checkout sales screen
entry.content:
Hello dear community members,

I have configured a period and volume discount in SAP Business One with a 15% discount for an item (ItemCode 109, original price 3300).

However, in SAP Customer Checkout, the item is displayed with the discounted price already applied (price shown as 2805). Because of this, cashiers cannot see the applied discount and cannot explain to customers that the original price is 3300 and the discounted price is 2805.

Is it possible to display the discount amount or percentage in the Discount column in SAP Customer Checkout? In SAP Business One it shows as expected, discount percent is another column.
Currently, the Discount column shows 0.

 

Thank you in advance for your support

SAP Customer Checkout @bikash_bansal @gunther_sandtner

entry.title: Re: How to use Custom Logic App to pass Contract Header d...
entry.content:
Hi @bigflatfoot ,

For the data transfer between Contract and Order I would recommend to use the BAdIs in Copying Control (SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD). You can find all the details here in the documentation.

The BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD is called multiple times during sales document processing which means also if you do any changes to the order, the BAdI will be executed again which is not needed in your case I think. If the interface of the BadI does not provide all the fields you need, please create a feature request via influence portal.

best regards,
Christian

entry.title: Re: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public vs Private Cloud
entry.content:
A crucial point to consider is an exit strategy - how are you going to get your data back when you get fed up with the cloud?

Even if there are no standard exit tools, custom data extractors can be build in Private Cloud. So there is a way out of the Private Cloud. Is there any out of Public one?

entry.title: Re: Purchase order accruals POAC and periodic billing plan
entry.content:
Hello Lakshmipathi

Thank you very much for this clear and detailled answer.

About the possibilities you give allow me to give a feedback for my own case (indeed all what you are suggesting would work) :

Split PO items by period
The use of a periodic billing in our company is also to make procurement work easier so I don't think business would accept to split a PO line into several

Use Service Entry Sheets (SES)
My company is already using SES (and no direct GR as we are buying almost only services and no goods). It works very well however it is very hard for us in term to get the requestor approve the SES. So invoicing plan was used as an alternative to SES

Custom enhancement (BAdI / substitution)
Indeed the may be the most relevant solution for us. as we are in Private Cloud

Alternative reporting
Thanks for this idea too that may suit our needs (even if it would add manual steps, it doesn't involve any custom abap development)

To sum up all what you are suggesting would work but option 3 and 4 are the most relevant for us.

So thank very much again for taking the time to answer and the high quality of your answer 🙂

Best regards

Thibaut

entry.title: AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) — The Adoption Operating Model
entry.content:
Part 3 of the “Practical Implementation Blueprint” series

Goal of this blog: Help you run AI in SuccessFactors like a product you operate, not a feature you enable once, so adoption stays trusted, measurable, and release-aligned.

Continuation from Part 1 & Part 2

In Part 1, we covered readiness, governance, identity/permissions, and the activation roadmap across Joule, embedded AI, and extensibility. In Part 2, we focused on the change blueprint: leadership ownership, frontline manager enablement, and operationalizing “AI suggests; humans decide”.

Now Part 3 answers what customers hit after go-live:
How do we run AI like a product -- safely, predictably, and aligned to SAP releases : without chaos, adoption drop-off, or budget surprises?

Series navigation: If you’re just starting with this blog, I recommend reading the first two posts first, then continuing here with Part 3.

  • Part 1 — AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Practical Implementation Blueprint
  • Part 2 — AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Change Management Blueprint
  • Part 3 — AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Adoption Operating Model (this blog) 😊

Executive Summary (2-minute read)

The challenge: Many AI initiatives fail to scale because operating ownership, risk controls, and value tracking aren’t designed for continuous AI change. Gartner has predicted that a significant portion of agentic AI projects will be cancelled due to cost, unclear value, or insufficient risk controls.

The solution: Treat AI as a product you operate, not a feature you “turn on once.”

What you'll get

  • A minimum viable COE with clear accountability (and practical time allocations)
  • A three-tier governance cadence that stays agile without losing control
  • A single intake model that stops “random cool ideas”
  • A release-aligned quality loop so accuracy doesn’t erode over time
  • AI Units governance patterns using SAP usage metrics + dashboards
  • EU AI Act–aligned literacy + employment-risk handling patterns

Time to value (practical guidance)

  • 4–8 weeks to stand up basic governance + intake + dashboards
  • 3–6 months to stabilize the quality loop and embed monthly steering rhythms
  • 6–12 months to reach predictable “product mode” cadence aligned to releases

0) Why an operating model is required in 2026

AI in SuccessFactors is not static. You’re operating in a world of:

  • Joule capabilities evolving and relying on correct setup and permissions (for example, “Access to Joule” prerequisites).
  • Premium AI consumption monitoring through AI Units usage metrics and dashboards.
  • EU AI Act obligations, including AI literacy measures (Article 4 + EU Q&A).
  • Employment-related risk handling, because employment/worker management use cases are explicitly highlighted under Annex III (recruitment/selection and worker-management contexts).

That’s why mature customers shift from “AI rollout project” to an “AI product operating model.”

The 5 most common failure patterns (and how this blog prevents them)

Failure pattern
What happensPrevention strategy (where in this blog)
1) Orphaned ownership“Everyone owns AI” = no one owns it. Backlog becomes political. Adoption becomes inconsistent.Section 2 (COE roles + time allocation), Section 3 (cadence + decision rights)
2) Permission driftRBP/security changes break Joule journeys; users perceive “AI is broken.”Section 1.2, Section 5 (RBP impact checks + regression)
3) Random innovationMany custom skills/agents get built without lifecycle, test, support, or retirement plan.Section 4 (single intake + scorecard + decision tree)
4) Budget shockConsumption spikes appear when scaling cohorts or launching high-usage scenarios.Section 7 (monthly governance + spike diagnostic)
5) Quality erosionAccuracy and usefulness degrade release-over-release; no one notices until trust collapses.Section 6 (weekly quality loop + classification + fixes)

1) Operating model principles (2026 rules of the road)

1.1 One program, three AI surfaces

AI shows up in three interconnected layers:

  • Joule (assistant experience and guided support)
  • Embedded AI (AI-assisted experiences inside modules)
  • Extensibility (Joule Studio / SAP Build) for custom agents and integrations

Operating model implication: One intake, one backlog, one cadence, one measurement framework.

Illustrative example (common pattern): Organizations that consolidate Joule, embedded AI, and custom skills under one Product Owner and one backlog typically reduce duplicated initiatives and clarify the “which AI to use when” confusion faster than split governance models.

1.2 Security and permissions must remain “in the room” forever

Joule experiences depend on correct setup and permissions. As a result, security changes can “break” AI journeys even when AI itself is fine.

Concrete example of impact (permission drift):

  • You enable a manager-facing journey that relies on viewing team data.
  • Security/HR later tightens RBP visibility.
  • Result: managers hit errors or incomplete answers and conclude: “AI is broken.”

Prevention checklist

  • [ ] Security/Privacy has a permanent seat in Product Council (Section 3)
  • [ ] Every RBP change includes an AI journey impact assessment
  • [ ] Regression includes your top 10 AI-supported workflows (Section 5)
  • [ ] Support team has a “Permission vs AI” diagnostic script (Section 6)

1.3 Human-in-the-loop maturity progression

Part 2 made this clear: “AI suggests; humans decide.” Part 3 operationalizes it with maturity:

  • Level 1 (Basic): Generic disclaimer (“review output”).
  • Level 2 (Functional): Use case–specific guidance (e.g., drafting content requires compliance review).
  • Level 3 (Optimized): Contextual guardrails at decision points + manager coaching routines + auditable workflow markers (e.g., “AI assisted” indicator) for sensitive contexts.

1.4 AI literacy maturity model (EU-aligned, practical globally)

EU AI Act Article 4 expects organizations to take measures to ensure sufficient AI literacy for staff using AI systems. Treat literacy as onboarding + refresh + role-based deepening for high-impact roles.

Level
All employeesManagersHigh-impact roles (Recruiting, ER, Performance)
FoundationWhat AI can/can’t do; basic safety; where to find help+ HITL responsibilities; escalation paths+ Regulatory context; documentation expectations
PracticedQuarterly tips / refreshersManager community of practiceScenario-based practice
AdvancedSelf-service help centerCoaching othersAudit readiness + policy updates

2) AI COE structure with time allocations (minimum viable)

You don’t need a giant COE. You need clear accountability.

Role
OwnerTime allocation (guidance)Primary accountability
AI Product OwnerHR/HRIT50–60% FTEOutcomes, backlog priorities, adoption targets
SuccessFactors Platform OwnerHRIT30–40% FTEConfiguration, RBP changes, release impact, regression
BTP / Integration OwnerIT20–30% initially (higher if heavy Joule Studio use)Connectivity, extensibility lifecycle
Security + PrivacyCISO/DPO rep10–15% FTEPolicy, access risk, compliance sign-offs
Change & Enablement LeadHR Comms/L&D30–40% FTEComms, manager readiness, AI literacy plan
AI Knowledge/Content CuratorCOE/Ops20–30% FTEApproved sources, quality loop fixes
Adoption & Insights AnalystHRIT/HR Analytics20–25% FTEDashboards, ticket deflection, failure analysis

Sizing guidance (practical)

  • Small (<5,000 employees): combine roles; ~2 FTE total
  • Medium (5,000–25,000): ~3.5–5 FTE
  • Large (25,000+): ~5–8 FTE initially; higher at maturity depending on custom agents scope

3) Governance cadence with agendas (make it boring and repeatable)

Tier A — Executive Steering (Monthly/Quarterly)

Duration: 60 minutes

Standard agenda

  1. Adoption dashboard review (15 min)
  2. Risk register + top 3 issues (15 min)
  3. AI Units consumption vs budget (10 min)
  4. Value delivered vs business case (15 min)
  5. Go/no-go decisions (5 min)

Tier B — AI Product Council (Biweekly, 60 min)

Standard agenda

  1. Usage trends + top issues from last sprint (15 min)
  2. Intake review: new requests + prioritization (20 min)
  3. In-flight initiatives: status + blockers (15 min)
  4. Next cycle planning: what goes live (10 min)

Decision aids

  • Prioritization scorecard (Section 4.2)
  • Quality loop summary (Section 6)
  • Capacity planning + AI Units budget view

Tier C — AI Ops Review (Weekly, 30 min)

Standard agenda

  1. Hot issues from last 7 days (10 min)
  2. Quality loop: top 5 feedback themes (10 min)
  3. Quick wins for this week (5 min)
  4. Escalations + handoffs (5 min)

Practical embedding of managers

  • Rotate 2–3 manager representatives through Product Council quarterly
  • Monthly “manager listening sessions” (30 min) to capture friction
  • Include manager feedback scores in Tier A dashboard

4) Intake and prioritization (stop “random cool ideas”)

4.1 Single intake form (required fields)

  • Persona + workflow
  • Value hypothesis + metric
  • Data sensitivity
  • Human-in-the-loop requirement (yes/no + why)
  • Operational cost (support impact)
  • AI Units estimate + monitoring plan

4.2 Prioritization scorecard (weighted, transparent)

Dimension
12345Weight
Business valueMinimal impactNice-to-haveClear benefitHigh valueStrategic3x
FrequencyQuarterlyMonthlyWeeklyDailyMultiple/day2x
ReadinessMajor gapsSome gapsMostly readyReadyPlug-and-play2x
Risk/ComplianceHigh riskModerateStandardLowMinimal-2x
Consumption/CostVery highHighModerateLowMinimal-1x

Priority score formula

Priority Score = [(Value × 3) + (Frequency × 2) + (Readiness × 2)] - [(Risk × 2) + (Cost × 1)]
Maximum possible: 35
Minimum possible: -15

Prioritization thresholds

  • 25+ = Fast track (next sprint)
  • 15–24 = Standard backlog (sequence by strategic fit)
  • 10–14 = Consider (needs strengthening or cost reduction)
  • <10 = Defer or redesign

4.3 Intake decision tree (edge cases)

NEW REQUEST RECEIVED
│
├─ Is this employment-related (recruiting, performance decisions, termination)?
│  ├─ YES → Risk = 4 or 5 + Security/Privacy review required
│  └─ NO → Continue
│
├─ Do we have 3+ similar requests from different teams?
│  ├─ YES → Consolidate into one initiative (avoid duplication)
│  └─ NO → Continue
│
├─ Does this require NEW data sources or integrations?
│  ├─ YES → IT/BTP Owner assesses feasibility first (may delay 1–2 sprints)
│  └─ NO → Continue
│
├─ Is estimated AI Units cost >20% of monthly budget?
│  ├─ YES → Requires Tier A approval before piloting
│  └─ NO → Product Council can approve
│
└─ OUTCOME: Score using Section 4.2 + add to backlog with priority band

5) Release alignment playbook (SuccessFactors + AI)

Treat each SuccessFactors release as an AI change event: permissions/config shifts can break journeys, embedded behaviors can change, and custom agents need regression.

5.1 Release impact example (illustrative)

If permissions for a manager process change but your regression doesn’t include “Joule + that process,” you can generate a wave of tickets and a trust hit that takes weeks to recover.

5.2 Minimum release checklist (copy/paste)

  • Preview: identify impacted AI journeys; regression (top workflows + custom agents); refresh enablement (“what changed” + safe scope)
  • Go-live + 2 weeks: daily monitoring (tickets + wrong/confusing themes); rapid fixes (content, guidance, permissions); escalate defects to SAP if needed
  • Post-release: reprioritize backlog; update manager starter tasks (Part 2) with new value

6) The quality loop (how you reduce wrong/confusing outputs over time)

The goal is not perfection on day one. The goal is a repeatable improvement mechanism.

6.1 Weekly loop: Capture → Classify → Fix → Validate

Step 2: CLASSIFY (weekly)

Issue type
DescriptionExampleTypical fix
A) Missing/unclear contentPolicy/process info missing or outdated“Can’t find updated parental leave policy”Update knowledge source
B) Permission boundaryUser expects access they don’t have“Manager tries to view data outside role”Fix RBP OR clarify guidance
C) Low confidence/misinterpretationWrong/unclear response“Misread internal acronym”Add clarifying content; narrow scope
D) Product defectPlatform behavior/error“Error with valid permission”Escalate to SAP support
E) Misuse/unrealistic expectationUser asks AI to do unsafe things“Draft termination letter”Strengthen guardrails + enablement

6.3 Example quality improvement (before & after)

Scenario: Joule helps users find learning opportunities.

  • Before: results too broad; users say “not helpful.”
  • Actions: improve learning paths content + add guidance on better phrasing + apply scope rules.
  • After: users find relevant results faster; repeat usage rises; you scale with updated guidance.

7) AI Units governance (prevent budget surprises)

SAP provides AI Units usage metrics and consumption summaries so you can operationalize consumption governance. You should monitor consumption alongside adoption and value.

7.1 Minimum controls

  • Assign an AI Consumption Owner
  • Monthly consumption review: actual vs planned, spikes by cohort/process, 90-day forecast and guardrails
  • Scaling rule: no new cohort expansion until consumption trend is stable (or budget approved)

7.2 Monthly dashboard (Consumption + Value together)

Track consumption next to value so finance doesn’t only see “cost,” and HR doesn’t only see “adoption.”

Metric
This monthLast month3-mo avgTarget
AI Units consumed[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Cost per active user[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Tickets deflected[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Ticket deflection value*[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Net value (deflection − AI cost)[_____][_____][_____][_____]

*Use your internal cost-per-ticket assumption (e.g., service desk fully loaded cost).

7.3 Consumption spike diagnostic (runbook)

SPIKE DETECTED (>20% month-over-month)
│
├─ New cohort added this month?
│  ├─ YES → Expected. Monitor for next 30 days for stabilization.
│  └─ NO → Investigate further ↓
│
├─ New use case launched?
│  ├─ YES → Check if usage is appropriate. May need guardrails.
│  └─ NO → Investigate further ↓
│
├─ Seasonal pattern (e.g., year-end reviews, open enrollment)?
│  ├─ YES → Expected. Plan for next year.
│  └─ NO → Investigate further ↓
│
├─ Heavy user outliers (top 10% using >5x average)?
│  ├─ YES → Interview users:
│  │     • High-value power users? → Good. Feature in case study.
│  │     • Misuse or bot-like behavior? → Restrict or re-train.
│  └─ NO → Escalate to SAP (possible platform anomaly)

Compliance layer (EU focus, strong practice globally)

8.1 AI literacy (Article 4) must be a run-state deliverable

Treat literacy as onboarding + refresh + role-based deepening for high-impact roles. Integrate it into existing learning journeys (e.g., new manager onboarding) rather than creating isolated “AI training.”

Audience 
Initial (onboarding)Ongoing (run-state)High-impact (annual+)
All employees15-min module: what AI can/can’t do; where to find it; basic safetyQuarterly tips + refresh for new featuresSelf-service help center
All managers+ 30-min module: HITL responsibilities; escalation; “AI suggests; humans decide”Manager community of practice (quarterly)Scenario-based refresher
High-impact roles
(Recruiting, Performance, ER)		+ 60-min module: regulatory context; documentation expectations; bias awarenessQuarterly scenario practice + policy updatesAudit readiness workshop

8.2 Employment-related AI use cases require special handling

Maintain an AI Use Case Register for employment/worker-management contexts: classification, controls (HITL, documentation), sign-offs, and change history.

9) Measurement: ATVS dashboard (Adoption, Trust, Value, Safety)

Adoption

  • Active users (7/30)
  • Repeat usage trend

Trust

  • “I understand what’s safe”
  • “I know how to escalate”

Value

  • Ticket deflection
  • Time-to-complete improvements for top HR tasks

Safety

  • Permission boundary incidents
  • Register coverage for employment-related use cases

10) Visual framework: how it all connects

INTAKE → PRIORITIZE → PILOT → QUALITY LOOP → SCALE
   ↓          ↓          ↓          ↓           ↓
Product    Tier B     Tier C      Weekly     Tier A
Council   Decision    Review      Ops        Approval
   ↑          ↑          ↑          ↑           ↑
   └──────────┴──────────┴──────────┴───────────┘
              GOVERNANCE CADENCE
                     ↕
           RELEASE ALIGNMENT (each release)
                     ↕
         MEASUREMENT (ATVS Dashboard)

Key dependencies

  • Security/Privacy sits across governance tiers
  • AI Units monitored at Tier C, reviewed at Tier B, and steered/approved at Tier A
  • Quality loop feeds Product Council priorities
  • Release alignment triggers regression testing across all active use cases

11) AI operating model maturity levels

Level 1 — Initial (Months 0–3)

  • Basic COE roles assigned
  • Governance forums established
  • First pilots running
  • Quality loop mostly reactive
  • Ad-hoc consumption monitoring

Level 2 — Defined (Months 4–6)

  • Formal intake process
  • Prioritization scorecard in use
  • Weekly quality loop operational
  • Release regression testing begins
  • Not all use cases have HITL clarity yet

Level 3 — Managed (Months 7–12)

  • Predictable consumption forecasting
  • Value metrics tracked consistently
  • Manager enablement scaled (from Part 2)
  • Proactive quality improvements
  • Release process becomes predictable

Level 4 — Optimized (12+ months)

  • AI embedded in HR operating rhythm
  • Self-sustaining quality loop
  • Consumption + value balanced
  • Release process predictable
  • Expanding to new modules confidently

Your practical goal: Reach Level 3 by month 9–12.

12) Templates (copy/paste)

12.1 COE RACI (starter)

  • AI Product Owner — outcomes/backlog/adoption
  • SF Platform Owner — configuration/RBP/release regression
  • BTP / Joule Studio Owner — custom agent lifecycle
  • Security/Privacy — risk acceptance + sign-offs
  • Enablement Lead — literacy + communications
  • Knowledge Curator — source quality loop fixes
  • Support Lead — incident/problem/change coordination

12.2 Intake form (starter)

  • Title + owner
  • Persona + workflow
  • Value metric
  • Safe scope + HITL
  • Data sensitivity
  • AI Units estimate + monitoring plan
  • Pilot cohort
  • Definition of Done

12.3 Release checklist (starter)

  • Review “What’s New” items impacting Joule/AI journeys
  • Regression: top journeys + custom agents
  • Enablement refresh (what changed + safe scope)
  • Support script update
  • Post-release monitoring plan

If you enjoyed this series, I’d really appreciate a kudo, it really encourages me to keep writing more blogs 😊

Final note

In 2026, the goal isn’t “AI go-live.” The goal is habit + trust + measurable value : maintained through an operating rhythm. If you treat AI as a product you operate (intake, backlog, governance, release alignment, quality loop, and ATVS measurement), you significantly increase your chance of scaling impact without losing control of risk or cost.

entry.title: Re: Relational Dataset in Datawarehouse Cloud
entry.content: Just to Add on or I'm just putting it in another way round Relational Dataset is mainly meant to act as a neutral, foundational dataset in SAP Data Warehouse Cloud / Datasphere. You should use a Relational Dataset when you: Are staging or harmonizing data from multiple sources Need to join, filter, or prepare data before deciding KPIs Want a reusable dataset that can later feed Dimensions or Analytical Datasets Do not yet need analytics features like measures, aggregations, hierarchies, or SAC consumption In contrast: Dimension datasets are used for master data, especially when hierarchies, texts, and associations are required. Analytical datasets are required when you want to define measures, aggregation logic, and consume the model directly in SAP Analytics Cloud. So, a good rule of thumb is: If you don’t need the special features of Dimension or Analytical datasets, use a Relational Dataset as your base model.

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud 2602 Pre-Release Briefing
entry.content:
Hi All,

SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud (C4C) Pre-Release Briefing presentation for the upcoming 2602 (February 2026) release is now available.

We have some key innovations to be shared as part of SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud 2602 Release.

Platform & Integration:

Transition Tools:

  • Readiness Check Tool (RCT) | Pre-view showing ABSL code in “PDI Solutions” tab - The “PDI Solutions” tab now shows the preview of the ABSL code when you hover on the PDI solution.
  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | Additional Objects supporting Transfer - Visits, Route Planning, Account Hierarchy and Surveys are now supported in DTT as transferable objects
  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | PDI field data transfer is now available as GA - PDI field data transfer is now available as GA (not a BETA feature anymore)
  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | Transfer History extended to show different Transfer Types - Transfer History now reflects additional transfer types like Test Data Transfer, Extension field definition transfer, Business Configuration transfer etc.

PDI:

SAP Cloud Applications Studio installation process - Important Reminder

As you are aware and it was announced in SAP Sales Cloud and Service Cloud 2502 release roll out, the SAP Cloud Applications Studio installation process changed effective August 2025.  As of 2511 (November 2025) release Patch Version 1, SAP Cloud Applications Studio Extension supports devices running on ARM-based processors. The details are available in the SAP online help documentation link.

SAP Cloud Applications Studio (Pilot) will not be supported completely from 2605 release (May 2026). Please plan the migration if it is not done already.

SAP Sales Cloud:

  • Opportunity Management | Search for Opportunities using Product IDs in advanced search - Sales reps can now search for opportunities based on product IDs using the advanced find form without having to launch the filter conditions
  • ISE | Target Plans | Mass Upload Targets - Import targets via mass upload from target console:
    • Export a template pre-filled with selected sales unit or territory hierarchy nodes
    • Prepare or adjust targets offline in Excel or CSV format
    • Upload all targets in a single action

Thanks,

SAP Sales Cloud & SAP Service Cloud Product Management Team
